text:
| This article **needs additional citations forverification**. Please help
improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced
material may be challenged and removed.  
_Find sources:_ "Economy of Eswatini" – news **·** newspapers **·** books
**·** scholar **·** JSTOR _( November 2009)__(Learn how and when to remove
this message)_  
---|---  
  
The **economy of Eswatini** is fairly diversified. Agriculture, forestry and
mining account for about 13 percent of Eswatini's GDP whereas manufacturing
(textiles and sugar-related processing) represent 37 percent of GDP. Services
– with government services in the lead – constitute the other 50 percent of
GDP.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Eswatini is described as fairly diversified, indicating a range of different economic sectors contributing to national income.
• Agriculture, forestry, and mining collectively account for approximately 13 percent of Eswatini's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• The manufacturing sector, primarily comprising textiles and sugar-related processing, represents about 37 percent of the country's GDP.
• The services sector constitutes the remaining 50 percent of Eswatini's GDP, with government services being the leading component within this sector.
• The article notes that the information requires additional citations for verification, emphasizing the need for reliable sources to substantiate the data presented.

• Suggested sources for further information include news outlets, newspapers, books, scholarly articles, and JSTOR, with a specific call to action to improve the article's credibility as of November 2009.

text:
Title Deed lands, where the bulk of high-value crops are grown (sugar,
forestry, and citrus) are characterized by high levels of investment and
irrigation, and high productivity. Nevertheless, the majority of the
population – about 75 percent—is employed in subsistence agriculture on Swazi
Nation Land, which, in contrast, suffers from low productivity and investment.
This dual nature of the Swazi economy, with high productivity in textile
manufacturing and in the industrialized agricultural title deed lands on the
one hand, and declining productivity subsistence agriculture on Swazi Nation
Land on the other, may well explain the country's overall low growth, high
inequality and unemployment.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • Title Deed lands in Eswatini are primarily used for high-value crops such as sugar, forestry, and citrus, characterized by significant levels of investment and irrigation.
• These Title Deed lands exhibit high productivity due to substantial investment and modern agricultural practices.
• The majority of Eswatini’s population, approximately 75 percent, are employed in subsistence agriculture on Swazi Nation Land.
• Swazi Nation Land is marked by low levels of investment and productivity, leading to subsistence farming with limited economic output.

• The dual structure of the Eswatini economy features high productivity sectors, including textile manufacturing and industrialized agricultural Title Deed lands, contrasted with declining productivity in subsistence agriculture on Swazi Nation Land.
• This disparity between productive and less productive sectors is believed to contribute to Eswatini’s overall low economic growth.
• The economic structure also results in high levels of inequality and unemployment within the country.
• The contrasting agricultural systems and land tenure arrangements are central to understanding the economic challenges faced by Eswatini.

text:
Economic growth in Eswatini has lagged behind that of its neighbors. Real GDP
growth since 2001 has averaged 2.8 percent, nearly 2 percentage points lower
than growth in other Southern African Customs Union (SACU) member countries.
Low agricultural productivity in the Swazi nation lands, repeated droughts,
the effect of HIV/AIDS, and an overly large[_clarification needed_] and
inefficient government sector are likely contributing factors. Eswatini's
public finances deteriorated in the late 1990s following
sizeable[_clarification needed_] surpluses a decade earlier. A combination of
declining revenues and increased spending led to significant[_clarification
needed_] budget deficits. The considerable[_clarification needed_] spending
has not led to more economic growth and has not benefitted the poor to the
same extent as regional comparators, although the poverty headcount has
shifted slightly during the first decade of the 2000s (SHIES 2010). Much of
the increased spending has gone to current expenditures related to wages,
transfers, and subsidies. The wage bill today[_when?_] constitutes over 15
percent of GDP and 55 percent of total public spending; these are some of the
highest levels on the African continent. The recent[_when?_] rapid growth in
SACU revenues has, however, reversed the fiscal situation, and a
sizeable[_clarification needed_] surplus was recorded in 2006/07 and 2012/13.
SACU revenues today[_when?_] account for over 50 percent of total government
revenues. On the positive side, the external debt burden has declined
markedly[_clarification needed_] over the last 20 years,[_when?_] and domestic
debt is almost negligible; external debt as a percent of GDP was less than 20
percent in 2006.
openai_summarised_points: • Economic growth in Eswatini has lagged behind that of its neighboring countries, with an average real GDP growth of 2.8 percent since 2001, which is nearly 2 percentage points lower than the growth rate of other Southern African Customs Union (SACU) member countries.
• Contributing factors to the slow growth include low agricultural productivity in Swazi lands, recurrent droughts, the impact of HIV/AIDS, and an overly large and inefficient government sector.
• Eswatini's public finances deteriorated in the late 1990s after experiencing sizable budget surpluses a decade earlier, indicating a reversal in fiscal health.
• The decline in revenues coupled with increased government spending led to significant budget deficits, which have persisted despite efforts to stabilize finances.

• Increased government expenditure has not translated into proportional economic growth nor has it significantly benefited the poor, although the poverty headcount ratio experienced slight shifts during the early 2000s (as reported by SHIES 2010).
• A substantial portion of the increased government spending has been allocated to current expenditures, notably wages, transfers, and subsidies.
• The wage bill currently accounts for over 15 percent of GDP and constitutes 55 percent of total public spending, making it one of the highest levels on the African continent.
• Rapid growth in SACU revenues in recent years has reversed the fiscal decline, resulting in a sizeable surplus recorded in the fiscal years 2006/07 and 2012/13.
• SACU revenues now constitute over 50 percent of total government revenues, highlighting the country's dependence on regional revenue sharing.

• Over the past 20 years, Eswatini has seen a marked decline in its external debt burden, with external debt as a percentage of GDP falling below 20 percent in 2006, and domestic debt remaining almost negligible.

text:
The Swazi economy is very closely linked to the economy of South Africa, from
which it receives over 90 percent of its imports and to which it sends about
70 percent of its exports. Eswatini has great resources making a good trading
partner. Eswatini's other key trading partners are the United States and the
EU, from whom the country has received trade preferences for apparel exports
(under the African Growth and Opportunity Act – AGOA – to the US) and for
sugar (to the EU). Under these agreements, both apparel and sugar exports did
well, with rapid growth and a strong inflow of foreign direct investment.
Textile exports grew by over 200 percent between 2000 and 2005 and sugar
exports increasing by more than 50 percent over the same period. The continued
vibrancy of the export sector is threatened by the removal of trade
preferences for textiles, the accession to similar preferences for East Asian
countries, and the phasing out of preferential prices for sugar to the EU
market. Eswatini will thus have to face the challenge of remaining competitive
in a changing global environment. A crucial factor in addressing this
challenge is the investment climate. The recently concluded Investment Climate
Assessment provides some positive findings in this regard, namely that
Eswatini firms are among the most productive in Sub-Saharan Africa, although
they are less productive than firms in the most productive middle-income
countries in other regions. They compare more favorably with firms from lower
middle income countries, but are hampered by inadequate governance
arrangements and infrastructure.[_citation needed_]

Eswatini, Lesotho, Botswana, Namibia, and the Republic of South Africa form
the Southern African Customs Union (SACU), where import duties apply uniformly
to member countries. Eswatini, Lesotho, Namibia, and South Africa also are
members of the Common Monetary Area (CMA) in which repatriation and
unrestricted funds are permitted. Eswatini issues its own currency, the Swazi
lilangeni (plural: emalangeni), which is at par with the South African rand.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Eswatini is highly dependent on South Africa, receiving over 90 percent of its imports from South Africa and exporting approximately 70 percent of its goods to South Africa.
• Eswatini benefits from its abundant resources, making it a significant and advantageous trading partner.
• The country's other major trading partners include the United States and the European Union (EU).
• Eswatini has received trade preferences from these partners, notably under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) for apparel exports to the US and for sugar exports to the EU.

• Under these preferential agreements, both apparel and sugar exports experienced significant growth, with apparel exports growing by over 200 percent between 2000 and 2005, and sugar exports increasing by more than 50 percent over the same period.

• The export sector's growth is threatened by the potential removal of trade preferences for textiles, the accession of East Asian countries to similar preferences, and the phasing out of preferential prices for sugar in the EU market.
• Eswatini faces the challenge of maintaining competitiveness in a changing global environment due to these potential trade disruptions.

• An important factor in addressing this challenge is improving the investment climate; a recent Investment Climate Assessment highlighted that Eswatini firms are among the most productive in Sub-Saharan Africa.
• Despite this, Eswatini firms are less productive than firms in the most productive middle-income countries elsewhere but compare favorably with firms from lower middle-income countries.
• The productivity of Eswatini firms is hindered by inadequate governance arrangements and infrastructure.
• Eswatini is a member of the Southern African Customs Union (SACU), along with Lesotho, Botswana, Namibia, and South Africa, where import duties are uniformly applied across member countries.
• Eswatini, Lesotho, Namibia, and South Africa are also part of the Common Monetary Area (CMA), which allows for the repatriation of funds and unrestricted movement of capital.
• Eswatini issues its own currency, the Swazi lilangeni (plural: emalangeni), which is pegged at par with the South African rand.

text:
Eswatini enjoys well-developed road links with South Africa. Eswatini Railways
operates its railroads that run east to west and north to south. The older
east–west link, called the Goba line, makes it possible to export bulk goods
from Eswatini through the Port of Maputo in Mozambique. Until recently, most
of Eswatini's imports were shipped through this port. Conflict in Mozambique
in the 1980s diverted many Swazi exports to ports in South Africa. A
north–south rail link, completed in 1986, provides a connection between the
Eastern Transvaal (now Mpumalanga) rail network and the South African ports of
Richards Bay and Durban. From the mid-1980s foreign investment in the
manufacturing sector boosted economic growth rates significantly. Since
mid-1985, the depreciated value of the currency has increased the
competitiveness of Swazi exports and moderated the growth of imports,
generating trade surpluses. During the 1990s, the country often ran small
trade deficits.[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • Eswatini has well-developed road infrastructure with strong connectivity to South Africa.
• Eswatini Railways operates the country's rail network, which runs in both east–west and north–south directions.
• The older east–west rail link, known as the Goba line, facilitates the export of bulk goods from Eswatini through the Port of Maputo in Mozambique.
• Historically, most of Eswatini's imports were shipped via the Port of Maputo until recent years.
• The Mozambique conflict in the 1980s caused many Swazi exports to be diverted to South African ports.
• A north–south rail link, completed in 1986, connects the Eastern Transvaal (currently Mpumalanga) rail network with South African ports of Richards Bay and Durban.
• Foreign investment in Eswatini's manufacturing sector increased significantly from the mid-1980s, contributing to higher economic growth rates.
• Since mid-1985, the depreciation of the Swazi currency has enhanced the competitiveness of Swazi exports.
• The currency depreciation has also moderated the growth of imports, leading to trade surpluses.
• During the 1990s, Eswatini frequently experienced small trade deficits, indicating periods where imports exceeded exports.

text:
Eswatini is the fourth largest producer of sugar in Africa and is 25th in
production in the world. This demonstrates the immense focus of the industry
in order to continue to grow their economy. Eswatini's GDP was $8.621 billion
(US dollars) in 2014 based on purchasing power parity and of that 7.2% of that
is from the agriculture sector and of that sector, sugarcane and sugar
products have the largest impact on GDP. According to the World CIA Factbook,
wood pulp and sugarcane were the largest exports of Eswatini until the wood
pulp producer closed in January 2010. This left the sugarcane industry as the
sole main export. The largest company that produces sugar in Eswatini is the
Royal Eswatini Sugar Corporation (RES Corporation) and it produces a little
under two-thirds of total sugar in the country and produces over 3,000 jobs
for the people of Eswatini. The RES Corporation is composed of two main sugar
mill producers, Mhlume and Simunye, which produce a combined 430,000 tons of
cane per season. The second largest sugarcane company is Ubombo Sugar Limited
which has grown from producing 5,600 tons in 1958 to approximately 230,000
tons of sugar annually. The third largest sugarcane producer is the Tambankulu
Estate (largest independent sugar estate) and it produces 62,000 tons of sugar
annually on 3,816 hectares of land.

The largest export partners of Eswatini and the larger Southern African
Development Community (SADC) is the European Union. The SADC is a group of
many southern African countries who have banded together in order to try to
improve their individual socioeconomic status. In 2014-2015 the sugar
production of Eswatini was 680,881 metric tons and of this about 355,000
metric tons of sugar was shipped to the European Union, larger than any other
export partner. Another trade partner for Eswatini was the United States where
they shipped 34,000 metric tons of sugar in the 2014-2015 year under the
Tariff Rate Quota. These numbers are up from past years and continue to rise.
The expected output based on the 2015-2016 post forecast predictions are that
Eswatini will produce 705,000 metric tons, a new record for the country that
can be attributed to an increase in land being available for sugar
cultivation. Of this predicted figure about 390,000 metric tons will go to the
European Union as part of a new Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA). This new
agreement between the EU and SADC means that members like Eswatini can sell
their sugar on a duty-free and quota-free basis.

The quotas that the EU and the United States fill is similar to the Sugar
Protocol which began in 1975. The goal of the Sugar Protocol was for the EU to
purchase and import specific quantities from countries in Africa, the
Caribbean and the Pacific. These prices and quantities guaranteed production
and were well above the world price, which translated into substantial profits
for these mostly impoverished countries. This agreement reached an end in 2009
because the EU could no longer support the pre-determined demands. The Sugar
Protocol came to an immediate end and was replaced with separate Economic
Partnerships with the varying countries and regions. Even though the demands
will be just as high as under the Sugar Protocol, the prices will drop
significantly. In the case of Eswatini, they have received good reassurance
that their product will still be bought by the EU.
openai_summarised_points: • Eswatini is the fourth largest producer of sugar in Africa and ranks 25th globally in sugar production, highlighting the industry's significant role in the country's economic growth.

• The country's GDP was valued at $8.621 billion USD in 2014 based on purchasing power parity (PPP), with 7.2% of this GDP derived from the agriculture sector, where sugarcane and sugar products have the largest economic impact.

• According to the CIA World Factbook, wood pulp and sugarcane were Eswatini’s primary exports until the closure of the wood pulp producer in January 2010, leaving sugarcane as the sole major export commodity.

• The Royal Eswatini Sugar Corporation (RES Corporation) is the largest sugar producer in the country, accounting for just under two-thirds of total sugar production and providing over 3,000 jobs to Eswatini’s population.
• RES Corporation comprises two main sugar mills, located in Mhlume and Simunye, which together produce approximately 430,000 tons of sugarcane per season.
• Ubombo Sugar Limited is the second-largest sugarcane producer, having expanded from producing 5,600 tons in 1958 to approximately 230,000 tons of sugar annually.
• The third largest sugarcane producer is Tambankulu Estate, the largest independent sugar estate, which produces 62,000 tons of sugar annually on 3,816 hectares of land.

• The European Union (EU) is Eswatini’s largest export partner within the Southern African Development Community (SADC), which is a regional group of southern African countries aiming to improve socioeconomic conditions collectively.
• During 2014-2015, Eswatini produced 680,881 metric tons of sugar, with about 355,000 metric tons exported to the EU, making it the largest export destination for Eswatini’s sugar.
• The United States was another significant trade partner, with Eswatini exporting 34,000 metric tons of sugar in the 2014-2015 fiscal year under the Tariff Rate Quota system.

• Sugar exports from Eswatini are increasing, with projections for 2015-2016 indicating a record high production of approximately 705,000 metric tons, driven by increased land availability for cultivation.

• Of the projected 705,000 metric tons for 2015-2016, about 390,000 metric tons are expected to be exported to the EU under a new Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA), which allows duty-free and quota-free access for Eswatini’s sugar.

• The EU and the United States historically filled quotas similar to the Sugar Protocol initiated in 1975, which guaranteed specific import quantities and prices for African, Caribbean, and Pacific countries, ensuring above-world market prices and substantial profits for these nations.

• The Sugar Protocol ended in 2009 because the EU could no longer sustain the pre-determined demands, leading to the replacement with separate Economic Partnerships that maintain high demand but significantly lower prices for sugar.
• Despite the end of the Sugar Protocol, Eswatini has received assurances that its sugar will continue to be purchased by the EU under the new agreements, maintaining its export market stability.

text:
Currently, Eswatini's mineral sector is governed under a policy drawn up prior
to Eswatini's independence. In response to the sector's recent decline, a new
mining policy is being drafted by consultants, paid for by a grant from China,
and legislation to facilitate small-scale mining has also been proposed.

The country's main source of foreign exchange is the Bulembu asbestos mine,
however production has hit a steep decline. Diamond, iron ore and gold have
also been found in the past, however a lack of investment and development
policy has seen the region's potential falter.

Although fewer than 1,000 Swazis are directly employed in the mining sector,
many workers from Eswatini processed timber from the country's extensive pine
populations for mines in South Africa, and around 10,000–15,000 Swazis were
employed in South African mines. Their contributions to Eswatini's economy
through wage repatriation have been diminished, though, by the collapse of the
international gold market and layoffs in South Africa.
openai_summarised_points: • Eswatini's mineral sector is currently governed by a policy established prior to the country's independence, indicating outdated regulatory frameworks.

• In response to recent declines in the mineral sector, a new mining policy is under development, with consultants being paid for by a grant from China, highlighting international involvement and support.
• Legislation aimed at facilitating small-scale mining has also been proposed to potentially revitalize the sector and promote local participation.
• The Bulembu asbestos mine serves as the country's primary source of foreign exchange; however, its production has experienced a significant decline, impacting national revenue.

• Historically, Eswatini has been known to possess deposits of diamonds, iron ore, and gold, but these resources have not been fully exploited due to insufficient investment and underdeveloped policies.
• The lack of investment and effective development policies has hindered the realization of the region’s mineral potential, leading to underperformance in resource extraction.
• Fewer than 1,000 Swazis are directly employed within the formal mining sector, indicating limited local employment opportunities in mining activities.
• Many Swazi workers have historically processed timber from Eswatini’s extensive pine forests for mines located in South Africa, demonstrating regional economic interdependence.
• An estimated 10,000 to 15,000 Swazis were employed in South African mines, contributing to Eswatini's economy through wage remittances.
• The contribution of Swazi workers to the national economy has diminished due to the collapse of the international gold market and subsequent layoffs in South African mining industries.
• The section presents a comprehensive overview of Eswatini's main economic indicators from 1980 to 2017, highlighting trends and changes over nearly four decades.
• In 1980, Eswatini's GDP measured approximately 0.90 billion US dollars in Purchasing Power Parity (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 1,653 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 0.75 billion US dollars.
• The economy experienced a decline in 1980 with a real GDP growth rate of -3.8%, accompanied by an inflation rate of 18.2%.
• By 1985, GDP increased to 1.50 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 2,359 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 0.50 billion US dollars, reflecting economic growth.
• The GDP growth rate in 1985 was positive at 3.8%, and inflation rose slightly to an unspecified percentage, with government debt at 20.5% of GDP.

• In 1990, GDP further increased to 2.95 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 3,793 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 1.24 billion US dollars, with a significant real GDP growth of 8.9%.
• Inflation in 1990 was 13.1%, and government debt decreased to 13.1% of GDP.

• The mid-1990s saw continued growth: in 1995, GDP reached 3.84 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 4,421 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 1.93 billion US dollars; GDP growth was 4.0%, and government debt was 12.3%.
• By 2000, GDP was 4.83 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 5,033 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 1.74 billion US dollars; growth slowed to 2.6%, with government debt at 12.2%.

• The period from 2005 to 2008 shows steady economic expansion: in 2005, GDP was 6.52 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 6,537 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 3.18 billion US dollars; GDP growth was 5.5%, and government debt was 1.8%.
• In 2006, GDP increased to 7.06 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 7,000 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 3.29 billion US dollars; growth was 5.2%, government debt at 5.2%.
• The 2007 data shows GDP at 7.54 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 7,387 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 3.47 billion US dollars; GDP growth was 3.9%, government debt at 8.1%.

• In 2008, GDP reached 7.90 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 7,658 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 3.30 billion US dollars; growth slowed to 2.8%, with government debt at 12.7%.

• The 2009 figures show GDP at 8.32 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 7,978 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 3.60 billion US dollars; GDP growth was 4.5%, government debt decreased to 7.4%.
• By 2010, GDP increased to 8.72 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 8,268 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 4.44 billion US dollars; growth was 3.5%, government debt at 4.5%.
• In 2011, GDP was 9.07 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 8,502 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 4.83 billion US dollars; GDP growth slowed to 2.0%, government debt at 6.1%.
• The 2012 data indicates GDP at 9.56 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 8,853 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 4.89 billion US dollars; growth was 3.5%, government debt at 8.9%.
• In 2013, GDP reached 10.18 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 9,317 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 4.60 billion US dollars; GDP growth was 3.5%, government debt at 5.6%.
• The 2014 figures show GDP at 10.74 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 9,712 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 4.43 billion US dollars; growth was 3.6%, government debt at 5.7%.

• In 2015, GDP was 10.97 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 9,807 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 4.06 billion US dollars; growth slowed to 1.0%, government debt increased to 5.0%.

• The 2016 data shows GDP at 11.11 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 9,814 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 3.82 billion US dollars; GDP growth was 0.0%, government debt at 8.0%.

• In 2017, GDP reached 11.34 billion US dollars PPP, with a per capita income of 9,884 US dollars PPP, and a nominal GDP of 4.41 billion US dollars; GDP growth was 0.2%, and government debt rose to 29%.
• Household income or consumption distribution indicates that in 2001, the lowest 10% held 1.6% of household income or consumption, while the highest 10% held 40.7%.
• Industrial production growth rate was estimated at 1% in 2001.
• Electricity production was 470 GWh in 2008, up from 420 GWh in 1998, reflecting growth in energy output.
• Electricity consumption increased from 962.9 GWh in 2001 to 1,078 GWh in 1998, and further to 1,207 GWh in 2008.
• Electricity exports were zero kilowatt-hours in 2009, 2001, and 1998, indicating no electricity exports during these years.
• Electricity imports were 768 GWh in 2009, 639 GWh in 2001, and 687 GWh in 1998, with about 60% of imports sourced from South Africa as of 2009.
• The national currency is the lilangeni (E), subdivided into 100 cents.

• Exchange rates fluctuated over the years, with the lilangeni pegged at par with the South African rand; notable rates include 7.3 emalangeni per US dollar in 2011, 7.32 in 2010, 8.42 in 2009, and 6.9398 in 2000.
• Other exchange rates include 10.5407 in 2002, 8.6092 in 2001, 6.1087 in 1999, and 4.6032 in 1997, reflecting currency stability and fluctuations over time.
